Award.AwardTitle: Improved Modeling and Measurement of the Geographic Spread of Invasive Organisms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates the effects of wind and other "directional" factors that contribute to the spread of invasive organisms like insects. Most researchers who study insect dispersion discuss factors like wind direction and human transport, but these factors are rarely included in models because of their complexity and relative unpredictability. However, circular statistics calculated from wind data can be used to randomly select dispersal directions and distances. When repeated many times, these models produce probability maps showing the likelihood that invasive insects will move to a given location. Since direction is such an important element of dispersal, since current models fail to adequately account for directional spread, and since invasive species promise to be a problem for years to come, this research may be the most significant advance in species distribution models in recent years.

These maps will help land managers that combat detrimental invasive species focus their efforts in areas of greater risk, saving tax money as well as ecosystems and natural resources. While wind are the initial focus, the methods can also be applied to factors like transport along roadways, movement toward preferred environments, and other factors that push or pull organisms to new areas. The results of this research, including derived datasets, maps, and computer models, will be submitted to data.gov to ensure their accessibility by other researchers, will be explained through science articles, and will be shared with land managers, including National Parks Service personnel who are collaborating on the project. Over the three year period of this project, roughly 20 undergraduate students will participate in data collection and nearly 100 will assist in analyzing data during laboratory exercises during classes. Most of these students will pursue environmental careers using digital mapping technology, but many will become K-12 teachers who will share this experience with their students and thereby encourage them to pursue environmental science careers. The researcher is particularly committed to increasing female students' participation in this project, since they are underrepresented in this field nationwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Climate change does not affect all species equally. Some, like trees, have a very narrow range of habitat conditions and they evolve very slowly, making them very susceptible to changes in their environment. Others organisms, like insects, are more robust and evolve quickly enough to adapt and to take advantage of new ecosystem niches. Many of the most dangerous invasive species moving around the world today are insects that consume plants. The plants, who are already threatened by climate change, are forced to contend with predatory insects which thrive in the new conditions. We cannot effectively combat the threat of invasive species and care for our natural and agricultural environments if we do not know the location and the severity of the infestation. 

Using satellite imagery, we can look for ecosystem disturbances on a global scale. Some satellites even allow us to examine the entire Earth’s surface everyday. One significant weakness, however, is that the disturbance must be large enough and severe enough to be seen in the imagery. In other words, satellite imagery is good at telling us where a disturbance has already occurred and where an invasive species is already established, but it is much harder to detect the disturbance while it is still small and easily treated. 

The researched funded by this NSF award address this weakness is two ways. First, we successfully increased the sensitivity of satellite algorithms to early, slight disturbances by creating statistically derived weights that exaggerate the disturbance to make it easier to see. Using this new method, we can find the invasive insect population earlier, which will give us more time to respond. Second, we have made, and will continue to make, advances in our ability to predict the future extent of invasive species’ territories. Specifically, we have made progress modeling the effects of winds, which frequently blow invasive insects to new locations. 

As a case study, we examined the European gypsy moth infestation in Northern Wisconsin, specifically in the Apostle Island National Lakeshore. Early results showed that the moth did not spread to the islands through graduate diffusion from the mainland. Some of the most heavily infested locations are on the most isolated islands. While some moths were surely carried to the islands by tourists, many of the most severely damaged sites are far from popular tourist destinations. Most of the heavily infested sites where on the eastern sides of the farthest islands, suggesting that they had been blown to the islands from across Lake Superior. Later research strongly suggested that they were blown there from the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, specifically the region around the Porcupine Mountains Wilderness State Park. If this is true, it would explain how gypsy moths arrived in Northern Wisconsin without having to make their around the bottom Lake Michigan and then move northward. It also suggests that the moths will arrive in Eastern Minnesota earlier than previous expected. This could effect Voyageurs National Park and the Boundary Waters Canoe Area. This research highlights the fact that effectively dealing with the gypsy moth infestation, and other invasive insects, will require coordinated efforts in multiple locations. An essential element of those efforts will the improved use of satellite imagery and more accurate spread models that those developed in this research project.
